author: By Jessie Heyman
title: ‘Titanic’ Is My Favorite Movie. There, I Said It.
description: A woman’s heart is a deep ocean of secrets; this is mine.
content: A year ago, I went on a date, and the guy asked me what my favorite movie was. A simple question, but I stammered. His brow furrowed. “Didn’t your profile say that you love movie quotes?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Israel-Gaza fighting escalates.
content: Some of the worst fighting between Israelis and Palestinians in years showed no signs of abating on Tuesday. Israel carried out deadly airstrikes in Gaza, and Hamas, the Palestinian militant group that runs the territory, fired heavy barrages of rockets at Tel Aviv and other Israeli cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: parable
description: This word has appeared in 94 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration Approves Nation’s First Major Offshore Wind Farm
description: The Vineyard Wind project, off the coast of Massachusetts, would generate enough electricity to power 400,000 homes.
content: Construction on the nation’s first commercial-scale offshore wind farm is expected to begin this summer, after the Biden administration gave final approval Tuesday to a project it hopes will herald a new era of wind energy across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Two Blue Dots on One Blue Planet’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Before the city pool in Johnson City, Tenn., got drained at summer’s end, dogs could take a swim for five bucks. Sporting his green life jacket, Barney leapt in as if he weren’t tired, deaf, toothless. We stayed until no one else was left. It’s a small thing in life, a dog, but small is relative. I packed biscuits for our last trip to the vet. I sat on the floor in the lobby, feeding Barney biscuits one by one, and for a moment it seemed possible that we might never run out. — Shuly Xóchitl Cawood
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Bill McCreary Dies at 87; Blazed Trail for Black Journalists on TV
description: He was hired at what became the Fox flagship station in New York in 1967, when there were few Black faces on the air, and became an Emmy-winning anchor.
content: Bill McCreary, an Emmy Award-winning reporter who was one of the first Black television journalists in New York, and whose perspective helped fill a noticeable gap in local public affairs reporting, died on April 4 in Brooklyn. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Fernando Tatis Jr. and 2 Yankees Coaches Test Positive for Coronavirus
description: San Diego’s Tatis was asymptomatic. Phil Nevin, the third-base coach for the Yankees, and Reggie Willits, the first-base coach, tested positive despite being vaccinated.
content: Even as the number of coronavirus vaccinations among Major League Baseball personnel slowly ticked upward, two teams announced on Tuesday that they were dealing with new virus cases. Three were rare breakthrough cases, in which a people tested positive despite being fully vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Leigh Heyrman
title: The Victorian Women Who Pierced Glass Ceilings by Speaking to the Dead
description: “Out of the Shadows,” by Emily Midorikawa, features six 19th-century women Spiritualists who defied gender norms to command public attention.
content: OUT OF THE SHADOWS Six Visionary Victorian Women in Search of a Public VoiceBy Emily Midorikawa
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxanne Khamsi
title: Is It Covid or the Flu? New Combo Tests Can Find Out.
description: New tests for respiratory illnesses can look for more than 20 pathogens at a time.
content: In January, a man in his 60s with heart disease and diabetes went to a South Dakota hospital with a cough and fever, worried he had Covid. A nurse swabbed the inside of his nose, and the sample went into a small device resembling an inkjet-printer cartridge, which was then placed into a machine about the size of a printer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: A Black Colonel Takes Command of a Key Marine Corps Brigade
description: The assignment gives Col. Anthony Henderson, whose promotion to brigadier general takes effect in July, further opportunity for advancement in a service that has had few African-American leaders.
content: WASHINGTON — The Marine Corps on Tuesday put a Black colonel in charge of one of its key fighting brigades, the latest in a series of steps that positions the Marine, Col. Anthony Henderson, for future elevation to senior leadership positions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carmen Maria Machado
title: Banning My Book Won’t Protect Your Child
description: My memoir could teach teenagers how to exit an abusive relationship. So why don't some parents want their children to read it?
content: When I was in my early 20s, I was in an abusive relationship with another woman. Soon after it ended, I did what I always did when I was heartbroken: I looked for art that spoke to my experience. I was surprised to find shockingly few memoirs of domestic violence or verbal, psychological and emotional abuse in queer relationships. So I wrote into that silence: a memoir, “In the Dream House,” which describes that relationship and my struggle to leave it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley
title: I.P.A. Signing Bonuses and Free Subs: Luring Labor as a Beach Economy Booms
description: Restaurants are cutting lunch hours and gas stations are paying signing bonuses as a beach town’s boom serves as a possible preview to the nation.
content: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del. — Dogfish Head Craft Brewery is struggling to hire manufacturing workers for its beer factory and staff members for its restaurants in this coastal area, a shortage that has grown so acute that the company has cut dining room hours and is now offering vintage cases of its 120 Minute India Pale Ale as a signing bonus to new hires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes
title: How the Golden Globes Went From Laughingstock to Power Player
description: The group that was once assailed by the F.C.C. steadily gained influence in Hollywood over the years until scrutiny of its practices and lack of diversity led NBC to say it would not air its show in 2022.
content: LOS ANGELES — The Golden Globes were created by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association in 1944 and quickly developed a reputation as unserious and slippery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $5 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Mayoral Candidates Respond to the Shooting in Times Square
description: The contenders said the episode was emblematic of a growing crime problem and moved quickly to describe how they would address the issue.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Pye
title: An Island Nation With Mighty Clout
description: “How Iceland Changed the World,” by Egill Bjarnason, offers a jaunty history of a small country with an outsize influence on global affairs.
content: HOW ICELAND CHANGED THE WORLDThe Big History of a Small Island By Egill Bjarnason
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: For Clean Energy, Buy American or Buy It Quick and Cheap?
description: President Biden says slowing climate change will create jobs. Tension between unions and environmentalists shows it’s not so simple.
content: Patricia Fahy, a New York State legislator, celebrated when a new development project for the Port of Albany — the country’s first assembly plant dedicated to building offshore wind towers — was approved in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Once Deal Makers, Biden and McConnell Are Miles Apart
description: Their longstanding relationship has so far yielded no trace of compromise. Now Senator Mitch McConnell says he is focused on stopping President Biden’s agenda in its tracks.
content: WASHINGTON — When Joe Biden won the presidency, hopes rose that he might be the rare Democrat who could finally crack the code of Mitch McConnell and find bipartisan common ground based on their shared past as Senate deal makers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Apple vs. Facebook
description: How a routine-looking software update became a major confrontation in the long-running conflict between two of the world’s largest tech companies.
content: Recently, Apple released a seemingly innocuous software update: a new privacy feature that would explicitly ask iPhone users whether an app should be allowed to track them across the other apps and sites that they use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Come to the Cabaret, Old Chum. Or at Least Stream It.
description: New concerts from Sutton Foster, Jeremy Jordan and Marilyn Maye offer examples of what the most intimate art form can and can’t do.
content: Cabaret is a magpie medium, plucking pieces from the world’s songbook and repurposing them to tell more-or-less personal stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Senate Panel Deadlocks on Voting Rights as Bill Faces Major Obstacles
description: Democrats now face the task of overcoming their own differences on the measure, and deciding whether they will use it as a vehicle to try to curb the filibuster.
content: WASHINGTON — A key Senate committee deadlocked on Tuesday over Democrats’ sweeping proposed elections overhaul, previewing a partisan showdown on the Senate floor in the coming months that could determine the future of voting rights and campaign rules across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Michigan Ignored Warnings About Doctor Abusing Athletes, a Report Says
description: A law firm hired by the university released a report about sexual abuse by Robert E. Anderson, who was a longtime doctor in the athletic department.
content: For more than 20 years, the University of Michigan ignored warnings that might have stopped a longtime doctor in the athletic department, Robert E. Anderson, from sexually assaulting “countless” students, including members of the wrestling and football teams, according to a report commissioned by the university that was released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: The White House will allow undocumented college students access to emergency pandemic aid.
description: A new rule coming from the Biden administration will allow “all students” to tap into some $36 billion in emergency stimulus funds flowing to colleges, including direct grants for those most in need.
content: The Biden administration said early Tuesday that it would issue a regulation allowing undocumented students access to some of the $36 billion in emergency stimulus aid flowing to colleges, a split from a Trump-era decision to bar those students — even among the federally protected ones known as Dreamers — from accessing earlier rounds of funding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Keith Haring’s Fabulous Friends Left Their Mark on His Fridge Door
description: A graffiti-tagged refrigerator door served as the artist’s guest register for Madonna, Angel Ortiz and more. Now it’s on the auction block at Guernsey’s.
content: It began life began as a white refrigerator door in an apartment in SoHo, but by the 1990s, it was anything but plain. It was covered with the graffiti tags and wide-marker signatures of the famous friends of the tenant in the apartment. “Madonna Loves Keith,” read one inscription.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Pinker
title: How Humans Gained an ‘Extra Life’
description: In Steven Johnson’s latest book, he looks at what he calls “one of the greatest achievements in the history of our species,” that life spans have more than doubled since the mid-19th century.
content: EXTRA LIFEA Short History of Living LongerBy Steven Johnson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: A Man Romanced My Daughter for a Green Card. Should I Report Him?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on turning someone in for attempted marriage fraud, telling a friend about his cheating wife — and more.
content: My adult daughter met a nice young man. They went for a hike. He brought along a man from an Eastern European country here on a work visa. There was chemistry between my daughter and this man, and they started spending time together; the original guy immediately stepped aside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Sharon Otterman
title: Uber and Lyft will provide free rides to vaccination sites until July 4, Biden says.
description: The agreement is one of several new measures the White House hopes will help the nation reach 160 million fully vaccinated adults by the holiday.
content: President Biden said on Tuesday that Uber and Lyft, two of the country’s largest ride-sharing services, would provide free rides to vaccination sites beginning May 24, an agreement intended to help stem the declining pace of immunizations and reach his goal of at least partly inoculating 70 percent of American adults by July 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: ‘Staggering’ Legal Fees in Boy Scouts Bankruptcy Case
description: As the Boy Scouts of America goes through a contentious bankruptcy, dozens of lawyers are working on the case. Many are charging more than $1,000 an hour.
content: One lawyer negotiating a resolution to the multi-billion-dollar bankruptcy filed by the Boy Scouts of America billed $267,435 in a single month. Another charged $1,725 for each hour of work. New lawyers fresh out of law school have been billing at an hourly rate of more than $600.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gordon Jones
title: Tamika Catchings Is Taking Her ‘Superpower’ to the Hall of Fame
description: Catchings, a 10-time W.N.B.A. All-Star, said her hearing loss helped her have greater court awareness and better anticipate her opponents’ moves.
content: Over time, Tamika Catchings reached an understanding about her lifelong hearing impairment. If it had once led to childhood taunts and later to some communication breakdowns with her college basketball coach, Tennessee’s Pat Summitt, Catchings came to realize that her impairment wasn’t an impairment at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What Is Your Relationship With the Weight-Loss Industry?
description: One essayist says that we should resist its marketing, that diets don’t work and that the language of diet culture can be dangerous. Do you agree?
content: Have you heard about the “quarantine 15”? Are ads for diets and fitness apps filling your feeds right now? How do you react to them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: China’s ‘Long-Term Time Bomb’: Falling Births Stunt Population Growth
description: Only 12 million babies were born last year, the lowest number of births since 1961, providing fresh evidence of a looming demographic crisis that could complicate Beijing’s ambitions.
content: China’s population is growing at its slowest pace in decades, with a plunge in births and a graying work force presenting the Communist Party with one of its gravest social and economic challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: ‘Selling the Family Jewels’: A James Joyce Landmark Is Set to Become a Hostel
description: A planned overhaul of the Dublin home that was the setting for the writer’s short story “The Dead” was opposed by writers, artists, academics and heritage groups.
content: DUBLIN — James Joyce famously left his native Dublin at the age of 22 and then spent the rest of his life writing about the city, sending characters to wander its slums, back streets and faded 18th-century grandeur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kerry O'Brien
title: A Piece of Music Will Speak Once More. For 26 Hours.
description: “I am sitting in a room,” Alvin Lucier’s classic work of sound art, will be performed by 90 artists in honor of his 90th birthday.
content: It was a snowy night in March 1970 in Middletown, Conn. But the composer Alvin Lucier turned off the heat, wanting it quiet in his apartment. He sat in his living room with two tape recorders, a microphone, a single loudspeaker and an amplifier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Williams Walsh
title: F.B.I. Asking Questions After a Pension Fund Aimed High and Fell Short
description: The Pennsylvania teachers’ retirement fund put more than half its assets into risky alternative investments. The math didn’t work out, spurring an investigation.
content: The search for high returns takes many pension funds far and wide, but the Pennsylvania teachers’ fund went farther than most. It invested in trailer park chains, pistachio farms, pay phone systems for prison inmates — and, in a particularly bizarre twist, loans to Kurds trying to carve out their own homeland in northern Iraq.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diana Kruzman
title: ‘It’ll Get Better’: Chaplains Play Essential Role for Transit Workers
description: Metropolitan Transportation Authority chaplains have long provided counseling to workers, a role that is even more important during the pandemic.
content: A few days after Frank Lamorte tested positive for the coronavirus, he got an unexpected phone call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss, Niraj Chokshi and David E. Sanger
title: Gas Pipeline Hack Leads to Panic Buying in the Southeast
description: The national average for a gallon of regular gasoline rose 2 cents on Tuesday, and some airlines began to take small measures in response to the shutdown.
content: HOUSTON — Panicked drivers scrambled to fuel their vehicles across the Southeast on Tuesday, leaving thousands of stations without gasoline as a vital fuel pipeline remained largely shut down after a ransomware attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Sui-Lee Wee
title: Key Takeaways From China’s Census Results
description: The country is locked in a demographic crisis. But the figures also showed rising education and urbanization levels.
content: Births are falling. The population is aging. The work force of the world’s second-largest economy is shrinking.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hollywood Has a New Way to Dramatize Addiction
description: Recent films dive into the profound grief experienced by so many families. What do they still get wrong?
content: The first words in the film trailer, spoken over ominous piano, come from a doctor with a grim prognosis. “I’m going to level with you, Molly,” he says. “Opioids have a 97 percent relapse rate.” This is an exaggeration, but it has its effect on Molly and her mother, Deb. Deb is a deer in headlights, eyes wrinkled from years of worryand mistrust. Molly looks like Kurt Cobain in zombie makeup: unbuttoned flannel, skeletal frame, sunken eyes, bleached hair, pallid complexion. “You have gone through this 15 times,” the doctor says, and then there’s a fast cut to Molly in a twin bed, twitching in the fetal position, withdrawing from opioids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Haifaa Al-Mansour Rocks Out to Punk and Cooks With TikTok
description: With her movie “The Perfect Candidate” arriving in American theaters, Al-Mansour, the first Saudi Arabian woman to become a feature-length filmmaker, discusses her cultural essentials.
content: When Haifaa Al-Mansour was a child, movie theaters were illegal. But the small Saudi Arabian town where she lived with her parents and siblings had a Blockbuster outlet. Her father, a poet, rented movies there often, “mostly to keep his 12 kids busy and out of his hair,” Al-Mansour said. She spent her childhood watching Hollywood hits, Bollywood musicals and Chinese martial arts flicks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: More Than 30 Dead in Gaza and Israel as Fighting Quickly Escalates
description: Hamas fires rockets at Israeli cities. Israel hits Gaza with airstrikes. Civilians suffer the most casualties, but leaders on each side may reap political benefits.
content: ASHKELON, Israel — The worst fighting between Israelis and Palestinians in seven years intensified on Tuesday night, as Israeli airstrikes began targeting Hamas offices in Gaza City and militants in Gaza fired rockets at the metropolis of Tel Aviv, the southern city of Ashkelon and Israel’s main airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Pope Francis Faces Another German Reformation
description: The liberal wing of Roman Catholicism tests how far a liberalizing pope will let them go.
content: For most of the Pope Francis era, the pope himself was the most turbulent figure in Roman Catholicism: dropping rhetorical bombshells, making unexpected gestures and appointments and using his power and influence to reopen debates his predecessors closed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: In Rebuke to N.R.A., Federal Judge Dismisses Bankruptcy Case
description: The N.R.A. filed for bankruptcy this year as it sought to end run regulatory action in New York, but a judge rejected the strategy.
content: The National Rifle Association’s attempt to evade a legal challenge from New York regulators was tossed out by a federal bankruptcy judge on Tuesday, in a ruling that cast further doubt on whether the group’s embattled chief executive, Wayne LaPierre, would remain at the helm after three decades in power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Hollywood Might Not Want to Save the Golden Globes
description: A comeback may prove difficult to mount, and the Critics Choice Awards or the SAGs could take their place.
content: The party’s over for the Golden Globes, at least for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Atlanta Spa Shootings Were Hate Crimes, Prosecutor Says
description: The district attorney in Fulton County will seek the death penalty against the suspect in the shootings, saying he targeted some victims because they were of Asian descent.
content: A prosecutor said on Tuesday that the man accused of killing eight people at spas in and around Atlanta had targeted some of the victims because they were of Asian descent, and said she was planning to seek the death penalty against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Il Divo Tenor’s Ex-Wife Sues Him, Citing Sexual and Physical Abuse
description: Sébastien Izambard exerted “coercive control” over Renée Izambard and subjected her to years of psychological abuse and torture, she said.
content: A tenor in the classical crossover group Il Divo was sued Monday by his ex-wife, who accused him of domestic violence, sexual assault and battery and described his behavior toward her over the years as “a textbook example of coercive control.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Daniel Politi
title: These Three Feminists Are Changing Argentina From the Inside
description: Paying women for unpaid work at home. Delivering food to transgender people. Building day care centers. Bit by bit, these women, appointed by the president to high-ranking positions, are restructuring society.
content: — Vilma Ibarra, the top legal adviser to the president of Argentina
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Over 100 Republicans, including former officials, threaten to split from G.O.P.
description: Miles Taylor, a former Trump-era Homeland Security official who anonymously wrote a book condemning the Trump administration, is an organizer of the effort.
content: More than 100 Republicans, including some former elected officials, are preparing to release a letter this week threatening to form a third party if the Republican Party does not make certain changes, according to an organizer of the effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: The Biggest Dance Show in Town? At a Basketball Game.
description: Since February, the Brooklynettes have performed live at Barclays Center to crowds that are smaller than usual — but huge for dance.
content: I found an immersive performance — really, a spectacle — at a place I never would have expected it: a basketball game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The push to vaccinate teens.
content: The F.D.A.’s authorization yesterday of the Pfizer vaccine for 12- to 15-year-olds is a huge milestone in the battle against the virus, crucial for reducing its spread, reopening schools and returning to some sense of normalcy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Plot,’ by Jean Hanff Korelitz: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “The Plot,” by Jean Hanff Korelitz
content: Jacob Finch Bonner, the once promising author of the “New & Noteworthy” (The New York Times Book Review) novel The Invention of Wonder, let himself into the office he’d been assigned on the second floor of Richard Peng Hall, set his beat-up leather satchel on the barren desk, and looked around in something akin to despair. The office, his fourth home in Richard Peng Hall in as many years, was no great improvement on the earlier three, but at least it overlooked a vaguely collegiate walkway under trees from the window behind the desk, rather than the parking lot of years two and three or the dumpster of year one (when, ironically, he’d been much closer to the height of his literary fame, such as it was, and might conceivably have hoped for something nicer). The only thing in the room that signaled anything of an actual literary nature, that signaled anything of any warmth at all, was the beat-up satchel Jake used to transport his laptop and, on this particular day, the writing samples of his soon-to-arrive students, and this Jake had been carrying around for years. He’d acquired it at a flea market shortly before his first novel’s publication with a certain writerly self-consciousness: acclaimed young novelist still carries the old leather bag he used throughout his years of struggle! Any residual hope of becoming that person now was long gone. And even if it wasn’t there was no way to justify the expense of a new bag. Not any longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Productivity Tips
description: How do you get things done? What tricks, tips and hacks can you share with others?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Efforts to weed out extremists in law enforcement face resistance.
description: In the battle to stamp out extremism from the ranks of the police, state lawmakers have found themselves confronting a thicket of obstacles and somewhat unexpected opposition, ranging from partisan clashes to profound questions about protecting constitutional rights.
content: In the battle to stamp out extremism from the ranks of the police, state lawmakers have found themselves confronting a thicket of obstacles and somewhat unexpected opposition, ranging from partisan clashes to profound questions about protecting constitutional rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Checker That Makes it to the Other Side of the Board
description: Kevin Patterson urges us to keep it casual.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — This is Kevin Patterson’s second New York Times puzzle, and he has a piece of sage advice for us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Pat Bond, a Sexual-Subculture Pioneer, Dies at 94
description: Mr. Bond was a 44-year-old music teacher when he founded an organization for masochists. After a few meetings, sadists were also invited.
content: He was not a sex educator, a sex worker or a political figure. No case law was established in his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Michael Lewis Is Asking the Right Question
description: Why did America’s pandemic response fail so miserably?
content: Michael Lewis’s new book, “The Premonition,” is about one of the most important questions of this moment: Why, despite having the most money, the brightest minds and the some of the most robust public health infrastructure in the world, did the United States fail so miserably at handling the Covid-19 pandemic? And what could we have done differently?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Arizona G.O.P. Passes Law to Limit Distribution of Mail Ballots
description: The new law, signed by Gov. Doug Ducey, will remove people from a widely popular early voting list if they do not cast a ballot at least once every two years.
content: PHOENIX — Arizona Republicans passed a law on Tuesday that will sharply limit the distribution of mail ballots through a widely popular early voting list, the latest measure in a conservative push to restrict voting across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Krysta With a Y Plays Liza With a Z
description: For Krysta Rodriguez, who stars as Liza Minnelli in the new Netflix series ‘Halston,’ acting and decorating aren’t that far apart.
content: Krysta Rodriguez got her first look at New York City through the windows of the motor home that was ferrying her family around the country on an extended road trip. Along the way, there was a stop to take in a show — the 1990 Broadway revival of “Fiddler on the Roof.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Michael Lewis
description: The [DATE] episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Michael Lewis. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Do Democrats Have a Realistic Path Forward on Their Voting Bills?
description: As Republicans across the country restrict voting and federal legislation stalls in Congress, the left’s eyes are on Joe Manchin.
content: The Senate on Tuesday took up the For the People Act, a sweeping bill to overhaul the country’s election system, the first step in what will probably be a long and winding legislative process. Democrats are faced with not only the all-out resistance of Republicans, but also the hesitation of their own 50th vote, Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, the lone Democrat in the chamber who hasn’t signed on as a sponsor of the bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: The Lure of H Mart, Where the Shelves Can Seem as Wide as Asia
description: The huge grocery chain and other megastores like it have revolutionized the way many Asian-Americans shop and eat.
content: At the H Mart on Broadway at 110th Street in Manhattan, the lights are bright on the singo pears, round as apples and kept snug in white mesh, so their skin won’t bruise. Here are radishes in hot pink and winter white, gnarled ginseng grown in Wisconsin, broad perilla leaves with notched edges, and almost every kind of Asian green: yu choy, bok choy, ong choy, hon choy, aa choy, wawa choy, gai lan, sook got.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaitlin Menza
title: Vegas-Style Weddings Land in Brooklyn
description: The Sweet Hearts chapel, a new small events space, offers couples an affordable, all-inclusive experience.
content: It was a drizzling spring day in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and the “Dirty Dancing” soundtrack was playing in what used to be a mechanic’s garage at 57 Conselyea Street. The place is now a whitewashed room filled with red hearts. The current tenant, Julie Guinta, was clad in a triumphant marigold pantsuit as she welcomed a couple toting paper coffee cups in from the rain. Then she officiated their wedding ceremony in about the time it would have taken their drinks to brew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maurice Samuels
title: The French Count Who Turned His Home Into a Museum to Honor His Dead Son
description: “Letters to Camondo,” by Edmund de Waal, is addressed to a wealthy fin-de-siècle French Jew whose elegant Parisian home is filled with priceless objets d’art — and memories of the family that once lived there.
content: LETTERS TO CAMONDO By Edmund de Waal
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Can’t Help but Laugh at Trump’s Calling Horse a ‘Junkie’
description: Jimmy Kimmel called the former president “our own Triple Clown winner” in his monologue about a drug scandal involving the Kentucky Derby winner, Medina Spirit.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Hearst sells Marie Claire to a British publisher.
description: Marie Claire U.S. had been part of Hearst since 1994 in a joint venture with French company Marie Claire Album.
content: Hearst Magazines, the home of numerous publications aimed at women including Cosmopolitan, Redbook and Harper’s Bazaar, has sold the United States edition of Marie Claire to Future, a British publisher, the companies said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Henry
title: From Cape Cod to Martha’s Vineyard to the Caribbean, These Beach Reads Will Whisk You Into Summer
description: New novels by Jennifer Weiner, Sunny Hostin and Katherine St. John
content: THAT SUMMERBy Jennifer Weiner432 pp. Atria. $28.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Mary Jane,’ by Jessica Anya Blau: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Mary Jane,” by Jessica Anya Blau
content: Mrs. Cone showed me around the house. I wanted to stop at every turn and examine the things that were stacked and heaped in places they didn’t belong: books teetering on a burner on the stove, a coffee cup on a shoebox in the entrance hall, a copper Buddha on the radiator, a pink blow-up pool raft in the center of the living room. I had just turned fourteen, it was 1975, and my ideas about homes, furniture, and cleanliness ran straight into me like an umbilical cord from my mother. As Mrs. Cone used her bare foot (toenails painted a glittering red) to kick aside a stack of sweaters on the steps, I felt a jolt of wonder. Did people really live like this? I suppose I knew that they did somewhere in the world. But I never expected to find a home like this in our neighborhood, Roland Park, which my mother claimed was the finest neighborhood in Baltimore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Eakin
title: How Napoleon Became One of History’s Most Rapacious Art Looters
description: “Plunder,” by Cynthia Saltzman, recounts the French general’s vast thefts of European art and sculpture through the story of a single magnificent painting, Veronese’s “The Wedding Feast at Cana.”
content: PLUNDER Napoleon’s Theft of Veronese’s FeastBy Cynthia Saltzman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: White House Says Undocumented Students Can Receive Pandemic Aid
description: The rule reverses a Trump-era policy that barred the students from obtaining emergency aid to cover food, housing and school supplies.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration said on Tuesday that undocumented students could receive some of the $36 billion in emergency stimulus aid flowing to colleges, reversing a Trump-era policy that barred them from earlier rounds of funding that could help cover necessities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Glenn Youngkin Wins G.O.P. Nomination for Virginia Governor
description: Mr. Youngkin, a wealthy newcomer to politics who walked a line between the Trump base of the G.O.P. and business interests, will look to test Democrats’ strength in the blue-leaning state in November.
content: Glenn Youngkin, a wealthy first-time candidate who walked a line between his party’s Trump-centric base and appeals to business interests, won the Republican nomination for governor of Virginia on Monday. He heads into a general election in one of only two states choosing their governors in 2021, in the latest running of an off-year race often viewed as a referendum on the party holding the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: L Brands Plans to Spin Off Victoria’s Secret
description: The move came after takeover bids for the retailer were lower than expectations for a separate listing.
content: L Brands has decided to spin off Victoria’s Secret rather than sell it, DealBook is first to report. The company said last year it was considering separating Victoria’s Secret from the rest of its business, and we previously reported that it was testing private equity’s interest. Ultimately, sources say, L Brands has decided to split itself into two independent, publicly listed companies: Victoria’s Secret and Bath & Body Works. The deal is expected to close in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: One of the World’s Longest-Running Experiments Sends Up Sprouts
description: After lying dormant in buried bottles for 142 years, 11 seeds germinated on the Michigan State University campus after scientists planted them.
content: David Lowry was impatient for the very old seeds to wake up. For days, Dr. Lowry, an assistant professor of botany at Michigan State University, had entered a basement room at the school, peeked into the growth chamber and seen only dirt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kreda
title: Rangers Look to Move Past ‘Crazy’ Season
description: Another campaign ended without a playoff berth and with front-office changes for a team looking to take the next step in its rebuilding efforts.
content: The Rangers’ regular season may have been shorter than usual, but it was filled with turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Medina Spirit Will Run in the Preakness Despite Failed Drug Test
description: The trainer Bob Baffert said an ointment caused the colt to fail a drug test after the Kentucky Derby. He made a deal to keep the horse in the Preakness.
content: Cancel culture was not responsible for the Kentucky Derby winner Medina Spirit’s positive drug test. Nor was there accidental contamination, or a conspiracy at work. No, his trainer, Bob Baffert, said Tuesday, the colt was being treated for dermatitis with an ointment that he was unaware contained the drug in question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Glenn Youngkin, a wealthy businessman, wins the Republican nomination for governor of Virginia.
description: Glenn Youngkin, a wealthy first-time candidate who walked a line between his party’s Trump-centric base and appeals to business interests, won the Republican nomination for governor of Virginia on Monday. He heads into a general election in one of only two states choosing their governors in 2021, in the latest running of an off-year race often viewed as a referendum on the party holding the White House.
content: Glenn Youngkin, a wealthy first-time candidate who walked a line between his party’s Trump-centric base and appeals to business interests, won the Republican nomination for governor of Virginia on Monday. He heads into a general election in one of only two states choosing their governors in 2021, in the latest running of an off-year race often viewed as a referendum on the party holding the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Homeland Security announces new efforts to combat violent extremism in the U.S.
description: The department said the moves were part of a strategy to “comprehensively combat domestic violent extremism, including violent white supremacy.”
content: The Department of Homeland Security on Tuesday dedicated an arm of its intelligence division to target domestic terrorism and opened a new center to help state and local law enforcement combat violent extremists, the latest Biden administration efforts on the problem in the wake of the Jan. 6 siege on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: When It Comes to Taxes, Being Tracked Can Be a Good Thing
description: With remote work more common now, tax apps that track your location have become relevant for professionals who want to work wherever they want to live.
content: This article is part of our new series, Currents, which examines how rapid advances in technology are transforming our lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Humans Have Been Sharing Food With Animals for Centuries. Why Is That?
description: Researchers want to learn more about the connections between humans and the feeding of birds, beasts and other fauna.
content: In England and America, selling bird seed for feeders is a big business. In Delhi, people toss bits of meat into the air for black kites. Fleets of ships ply the oceans to catch fish for domestic cats, the descendants of predatory land animals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Israelis, Palestinians and Their Neighbors Worry: Is This the Big One?
description: The clashes could quickly blow over, or the unrest could blow up into another Intifada.
content: Let’s see, what happens when TikTok meets Palestinian grievances about right-wing Israeli land grabs in Arab neighborhoods in Jerusalem? And then you add the holiest Muslim night of prayer in Jerusalem into the mix? Then toss in the most emotional Israeli holiday in Jerusalem? And a power play by Hamas to assume leadership of the Palestinian cause? And, finally, a political vacuum in which the Palestinian Authority is incapable of holding new elections and Israel is so divided it can’t stop having elections?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: China Is Forcing Birth Control on Muslim Women in Xinjiang
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 11, 2021.
content: “The women of Xinjiang are in danger. The government wants to replace our people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: A Rare Tiffany Building Owned by a Nonprofit May Be Sold
description: Preservationists fear that the Ayer Mansion, a “national treasure” with landmark status, which has been painstakingly preserved, may be cut off from public access.
content: A granite-faced townhouse in Boston’s Back Bay neighborhood was designed more than 100 years ago by the artist Louis Comfort Tiffany and is seen today as the most comprehensive surviving example of his residential vision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: L Brands will spin off Victoria’s Secret instead of trying to sell it.
description: The retailer decided to split itself into two publicly listed companies, Victoria’s Secret and Bath & Body Works, in a deal that is expected to close in August.
content: L Brands has decided to spin off Victoria’s Secret rather than sell it, the DealBook newsletter was the first to report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser and Jade-Snow Joachim
title: Israel-Gaza, Spa shootings, Obesity drugs: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priyanka Runwal
title: The Price They Pay for Your Perfect Vacation Photo
description: Scientists are concerned about unregulated feeding of ocean wildlife by tour operators.
content: It took nearly three months, but Jody Pinder eventually succeeded. Endangered green sea turtles, usually shy, skittish and satisfied with a diet of sea grass and algae, were accepting handouts of squid that he and other local tour operators were providing at Bottom Harbor in the Bahamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: Novavax Reports More Delays for Its Covid-19 Vaccine
description: “I don’t see a lot going well for them at this point,” said one analyst.
content: Novavax, one of the first players in the race to vaccinate the world against Covid, delivered disheartening news on Monday, saying that its highly protective vaccine would not be authorized in the United States or Britain until at least July, and that it would not reach peak production until the end of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jose Solís
title: A Surprising First Live Show, in the Hometown I Once Fled
description: Back in Honduras for the first time in a decade, a critic finds hopefulness in a city’s cultural ferment — including an energetic theater troupe.
content: On March 12, 2020, I went to an afternoon movie. I was struck by the heavy feeling in Midtown; people looked less determined, more afraid. There were interminable lines inside the drugstores, and at the IMAX theater that seats more than 4,000 people, there was me and a stranger who walked in during the previews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ferren
title: Heading Home for the Vaccine: One Expat’s Trans-Atlantic Journey
description: With Europe’s vaccine campaign stymied, the Madrid-based author, along with his husband and children, boarded a plane for the U.S. “The act of taking matters into one’s own hands,” he writes, “can feel daunting.”
content: If Covid-19 has taught us anything, it’s to expect the unexpected. Outcomes that seem assured today may become impossible tomorrow — and vice versa. As an American living in Madrid for much of the last 20 years, I have deep roots in both Spain and the United States and, over the last 14 months, have often felt the pandemic unfolding at two different speeds — when one country has been relaxing protocols, the other has been restricting activity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
title: The Biden administration approves the nation’s first major offshore wind farm.
description: The Biden administration on Tuesday announced its final approval of the nation’s first commercial-scale offshore wind farm, a major step toward President Biden’s goal of expanding renewable energy production across the United States.
content: The Biden administration on Tuesday announced its final approval of the nation’s first commercial-scale offshore wind farm, a major step toward President Biden’s goal of expanding renewable energy production across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: A Financial Firm’s Collapse Reverberates as Its Founder Answers Questions
description: Lex Greensill’s company attracted attention in high levels of British government until it failed. Lawmakers are leading an inquiry.
content: LONDON — Greensill Capital collapsed because it lost insurance coverage for the loans it offered — not because of its risky business model, Lex Greensill insisted in testimony on Tuesday, breaking his silence more than two months after his company abruptly filed for bankruptcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Need a Reset? The End of Pandemic Life Can Be a Fresh Start.
description: Studies show that moments of disruption offer a unique opportunity to set and achieve new goals. The 10-day Well challenge will help you get started.
content: If there was ever a perfect time to make a life change, this is it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcia Chatelain
title: An Anti-Gang Activist, a Shooting and a Community Long Abused and Ignored
description: “The Holly,” by Julian Rubinstein, explores the history of gang violence in a historically Black Denver neighborhood, and the often misguided efforts of law enforcement agencies to reduce it.
content: THE HOLLY Five Bullets, One Gun, and the Struggle to Save an American Neighborhood By Julian Rubinstein
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Trump’s acting attorney general to affirm there was no evidence of widespread voter fraud in 2020.
description: Jeffrey A. Rosen, who served for the final month Trump was in office, is scheduled to testify on Wednesday about the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
content: The top Justice Department official at the time of the Jan 6. attack on the Capitol is expected to tell lawmakers on Wednesday that the department saw no evidence to undercut President Biden’s election win, even as Republicans continue to question the results and use those doubts to underpin restrictive voting laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: Puppets, Purses and Paintings, Too: An Overlooked Artist With Range
description: Sophie Taeuber-Arp blurred the boundaries between fine art and applied art, but died early without the recognition she deserved. A major new exhibition aims to fix that.
content: BASEL, Switzerland — Just over a century ago, during another pandemic, the Swiss Marionette Theatre in Zurich closed. The play “King Stag” ended its run in September 1918, after three sparsely attended performances. The Spanish flu kept its audience away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: A Glass Bridge. Gale-Force Winds. A Moment of Terror High in the Air.
description: Gusts blew out parts of a glass bridge’s flooring in northeast China, trapping a man and raising questions about the safety of similar hair-raising tourist attractions in the country.
content: A man who ventured out on a glass-bottom bridge in China’s northeast was left clinging to the side for dear life after gale-force winds blew away some floor panels, leaving gaping holes in the structure hundreds of feet above the ground, local officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Donner
title: Jobless Benefits Don’t Make People ‘Lazy,’ Nobel Laureate Esther Duflo Says
description: The desire to do meaningful work, and be respected for it, is more dominant than financial incentives, says Dr. Duflo, an M.I.T. economist.
content: — Esther Duflo, Nobel laureate in economics
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: Semiconductor makers and users form a group to push for chip funding.
description: The new coalition comes amid a global semiconductor shortage that has caused disruptions throughout the economy.
content: Semiconductor companies and big businesses that use chips have formed a coalition to push for tens of billions of dollars in federal funding for semiconductor research and manufacturing in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Violence in Israel Challenges Biden’s ‘Stand Back’ Approach
description: The president came to office seeing little opportunity to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. He may now be forced to get more involved.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden took office in January with little interest in pursuing an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement, for understandable reasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Suhasini Raj
title: Covid Desperation Is Spreading Across India
description: Infections, deaths and breakdowns that began in big cities a few weeks ago are rapidly advancing into rural areas, unleashing deep fear in places with little medical safety net.
content: NEW DELHI — Dozens of bodies washed up on the banks of the Ganges this week, most likely the remains of people who perished from Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here are some ideas on how to catch up on retirement savings after the pandemic.
description: For millions of retirement savers, the pandemic was a gut punch. There was the jarring stock market drop in March 2020, then millions lost their jobs, health insurance and ability to fund their savings.
content: For millions of retirement savers, the pandemic was a gut punch. There was the jarring stock market drop in March 2020, then millions lost their jobs, health insurance and ability to fund their savings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
title: Chandro Tomar, Who Shot Her Way Through a Glass Ceiling, Dies
description: Born in 1931, she found her calling late in life but inspired thousands of people, especially women and girls, through her passion for the sport of shooting.
content: NEW DELHI — Chandro Tomar first picked up a gun when she was around 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: What Are Puberty Blockers?
description: Recent conservative legislation has targeted a class of drugs used to treat transgender adolescents. But what do these drugs actually do?
content: When Sebastian Liafsha came out as transgender in middle school, his mother, Heather, jumped into research mode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A Wandering Tiger Unnerved Houston. The Man Who Fled With It Is a Murder Suspect.
description: The man who was seen with the big cat was taken into custody on Monday night, the police said. But the tiger’s whereabouts remained unknown.
content: A Bengal tiger wandered through a residential neighborhood in Houston on Sunday, startling homeowners — at least one of whom drew his gun — and setting off a hunt for a man who drove off with the animal, and who the authorities said had been charged with murder and released on bond in a 2017 killing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Tensions flare in Jerusalem.
content: Weeks of clashes in Jerusalem veered into military conflict yesterday after a raid by the Israeli police on Al Aqsa Mosque. Militants in Gaza responded by firing rockets at the city, drawing Israeli airstrikes in return. Palestinian health officials said at least 20 residents of northern Gaza, including nine children, were killed in the airstrikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Rubin
title: Can’s Live Shows Will Be Heard at Last, Thanks to a Bootlegger in Big Pants
description: A series of concert albums by the influential German band were made possible by Andrew Hall, a fan who followed the group around in the 1970s with a Sony cassette recorder hidden in his trousers.
content: In February 1972, following the surprise success of the single “Spoon,” the experimental rock group Can staged a massive free concert in its Cologne, West Germany, hometown. To better entertain the crowd, it punctuated the music with a slapdash circus, including a juggler, a singing saw player and a team of acrobats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Cheney Embraces Her Downfall, Warning G.O.P. of Trump in a Fiery Speech
description: “I will not sit back and watch in silence while others lead our party down a path that abandons the rule of law,” Representative Liz Cheney said on the eve of a vote to remove her from House Republican leadership.
content: WASHINGTON — In the hours before facing a vote that will almost certainly purge her from House Republican leadership, Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming remained unrepentant on Tuesday, framing her expulsion as a turning point for her party and declaring in an extraordinary speech that she would not sit quietly by as Republicans abandoned the rule of law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jules Boykoff
title: A Sports Event Shouldn’t Be a Superspreader. Cancel the Olympics.
description: The International Olympic Committee cares about its relentless pursuit of profit, not public health.
content: The Tokyo Olympics are in big trouble. Postponed by a year and slated to begin in July, the Olympics have become a political flash point in Japan, where almost 60 percent of the population opposes staging the Games this summer and where less than 2 percent of the population is vaccinated for Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: It’s a Home in Brooklyn. What Could It Cost? $100,000?
description: Shaun Donovan and Raymond J. McGuire, candidates for mayor of New York, were way, way off when asked to estimate the median home price in the borough.
content: Do you know the median sales price for a home in Brooklyn?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Can You Have More Than 150 Friends?
description: A new study questions that figure, known as Dunbar’s number. The Oxford professor for whom it is named, Robin Dunbar, dismissed the findings as “absolutely bonkers.”
content: LONDON — Just how many friends can one person have?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: A Gallery Featuring Only Artists of Color Feels Like Change
description: “Shattered Glass” at Deitch Gallery in Los Angeles has visitors returning, and artists bonding.
content: LOS ANGELES — People have come back again and again. They bring family members and friends. It isn’t often that a gallery show engenders such strong responses. But this one feels different, because every face in every painting belongs to a person of color. Every piece of art was created by a person of color. And the exhibition was organized by two young people of color curating their first major show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kari Molvar
title: The Beauty Stores, Near and Far, That Are Destinations in Their Own Right
description: Sought-out spots for picking up finely milled soaps, hand-sculpted makeup brushes, exquisite scents and more.
content: Beautifying ourselves, and seeking out the best inventions with which to do so, has been a source of comfort for millenniums. In Egypt’s Karnak village, beginning in the 16th century B.C., temples served as early shops and produced scented oils used for perfuming the living, embalming the dead, softening the skin and hair, covering up bad breath and easing sore muscles. In 17th-century Europe, apothecaries sold raw materials — plant oils, mineral powders — that enabled patrons to whip up their own potions to disguise concerns such as gray hair and wrinkles. And as the definition of beauty has evolved, so, too, has the function of the beauty shop. Today, when we tend to think of beauty in more holistic terms, the places that sell creams, powders and pigments are often more than merely points for picking up curative goods: They can be sanctuaries for gathering, broadening the mind, stimulating the senses and perhaps even stirring the soul. In a year when it’s been difficult to physically visit shops, their value has never been more apparent. Here, as part of T’s Beauty & Luxury issue, we pay tribute to just some of our favorite beauty institutions — the sort of spots that feel like discoveries — from a centuries-old perfumery in New Delhi to a sustainably minded apothecary in Vienna to a futuristic emporium-cum-gallery in Seoul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Efforts to Weed Out Extremists in Law Enforcement Meet Resistance
description: Oregon, California, Minnesota, Tennessee and Washington, D.C., are seeking to give law enforcement agencies more power to exclude officers with ties to extremist groups.
content: In the battle to stamp out extremism from the ranks of the police, lawmakers from California to Minnesota have proposed solutions they thought were straightforward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman
title: How Did We Get So Stuck on Here?
description: Our complicated relationship with social media might be simpler than it feels. Just remember how it started.
content: It’s a testament to the power of the biggest social platforms that many common complaints about them sound contradictory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams and Katie Robertson
title: Washington Post Names A.P. Editor, Sally Buzbee, as Its Top Editor
description: After more than three decades at a respected news service, Ms. Buzbee becomes the successor to the star editor Martin Baron.
content: After nearly a decade of revitalization under the ownership of the multibillionaire Jeff Bezos and the newsroom leadership of Martin Baron, The Washington Post announced on Tuesday that it had selected Sally Buzbee, the executive editor of The Associated Press, as its next top editor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: In a Firm Voice, Queen Opens U.K. Parliament
description: The government plans laid out in the Queen’s Speech suggest that Prime Minister Boris Johnson intends to make full use of favorable political conditions.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson hoped to use the opening of Britain’s Parliament on Tuesday to galvanize his government’s agenda after a striking series of victories in regional elections in England last week. But the spotlight shone brightest on Queen Elizabeth II, who appeared in public for the first time since burying her husband, Prince Philip, to handle the age-old pageantry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: To Vaccinate Younger Teens, States and Cities Look to Schools, Camps, Even Beaches
description: The F.D.A.’s authorization of Pfizer’s Covid shot for 12- to 15-year-olds is a milestone in battling the coronavirus, but actually getting them vaccinated involves new challenges.
content: The race is on to vaccinate the nation’s nearly 17 million 12- to 15-year-olds against Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Why a Lifelong Republican Views Arizona’s Recount as Wrong
description: Bill Gates, an election supervisor in Maricopa County, says the audit of votes in his state is based on the lie of election fraud, and is “tearing at the foundations of our democracy.”
content: For several weeks, Republicans in Arizona have conducted an extraordinary audit into the results of November’s presidential election, drawing scrutiny and widespread criticism for examining ballots without any evidence of fraud, and instead relying on conspiracy theories. The audit is expected to continue for weeks, if not months, prodded on by Republicans in the State Legislature, who have perpetuated former President Donald J. Trump’s falsehood that the election was stolen from him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard North Patterson
title: Stacey Abrams’s Legal Thriller Has Many Moving Pieces
description: In “While Justice Sleeps,” the veteran author and voting rights activist takes on the Supreme Court, biotech and blackmail — among other topics.
content: WHILE JUSTICE SLEEPSBy Stacey Abrams
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julekha Dash
title: Second Life for Shipping Containers: Selling Bao Buns and Baked Goods
description: The brightly colored steel boxes are being repurposed by developers in an effort to liven up bars, cafes and restaurants inside food halls.
content: To drum up publicity for his downtown Indianapolis food hall, Craig Baker posted photos of orange, turquoise and hot pink shipping containers on Instagram. They might seem like an odd way to promote a food emporium and culinary incubator, but the steel boxes piqued locals’ curiosity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: LaMelo Ball Talks Wild Passes, Rookie of the Year and ‘Space Jam’
description: Ball, the Charlotte Hornets guard, is one of the season’s standout players, and not just among rookies. The secret to his shot? “Just shoot it with confidence.”
content: A fractured wrist is about the only thing that has stopped Charlotte Hornets guard LaMelo Ball. The injury cut 21 games from his rookie season. He recently picked up where he left off, lobbing a nearly full-court, pinpoint underhand pass in his first game back, against the Detroit Pistons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: In Virginia, a Fight Over the Suburbs in the Governor’s Race
description: Glenn Youngkin, a first-time candidate with vast wealth, will deliver a pro-business message intended to win over suburban voters. Democrats plan to portray him as a Trump devotee.
content: Republican voters’ choice for Virginia governor, a deep-pocketed first-time candidate who plans to run as a business-friendly political outsider, will offer a major test in the post-Trump era of the party’s ability to win back suburban voters who have fled over the past four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allegra Goodman
title: The Babysitter Knows All
description: In Jessica Anya Blau’s new novel, “Mary Jane,” a 14-year-old receives an education from the family she works for — and delivers one in return.
content: MARY JANEBy Jessica Anya Blau
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: What to Know About Newsom’s Big Budget Surplus Plan
description: Tuesday: Gov. Gavin Newsom has proposed giving at least $600 to millions of California taxpayers.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Robert Slavin, Who Studied How Children Learn, Dies at 70
description: He favored phonics to teach reading and grouping students with different aptitudes rather than by age or grade.
content: Robert E. Slavin, a sociologist whose rigorous research into how children learn helped shift the emphasis in classrooms across the country toward teaching reading through phonics, mixing students of different aptitudes rather than educating them on separate tracks, and testing them for vision and other factors that could affect their education, died on April 24 in Baltimore. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Diet Companies See Gains as Americans Try to Drop Pandemic Pounds
description: In recent weeks and months, as people have ventured out more often, business has jumped for companies that sell plans to help lose weight.
content: Maybe it was the frozen pizza. Or the cheesy snack crackers she mindlessly nibbled on as she worked from home over the past year. Or those darn cookies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Why Is New TV So Much Like Cable?
description: The standard business practices developing around streaming entertainment are rotten and need to change.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russia School Shooting Kills 7 Students and 2 Employees
description: Within hours of the shooting in Kazan, a provincial capital, President Vladimir V. Putin said he had ordered a tightening of Russia’s already restrictive laws on civilian ownership of guns.
content: MOSCOW — Gunfire and explosions erupted at a school in central Russia on Tuesday, killing seven students and two school employees, according to witnesses and officials who blamed a teenager for the rare mass shooting in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: The Trump G.O.P.’s Plot Against Liz Cheney — and Our Democracy
description: Wednesday's House leadership vote is one step among many that will hurt America.
content: I met a girl who sang the bluesAnd I asked her for some happy newsBut she just smiled and turned away
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Nagourney
title: Norman Lloyd, Veteran Hollywood Hyphenate, Is Dead at 106
description: In his long career as an actor, producer and director, he worked with some of the best-known names in show business, even if his own was barely recognized.
content: He was the young actor who moved the audience as Cinna the poet in Orson Welles’s 1937 theatrical production of “Julius Caesar.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Colombia Police Respond to Protests With Bullets, and Death Toll Mounts’
description: In this lesson, you will learn why people are demonstrating, as well as why experts say these protests could “presage unrest across Latin America.”
content: Featured Article: “Colombia Police Respond to Protests With Bullets, and Death Toll Mounts” by Julie Turkewitz and Sofía Villamil
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Shootings and Subway Attacks Put Crime at Center of N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race
description: Rising concerns over crime have led candidates to issue strong appeals for public safety, less than a year after the city was under pressure to defund the police.
content: A shooting in Times Square, a spike in gun violence and a spate of high-profile attacks on subway riders have pushed concerns over crime and public safety to the forefront of the New York City mayor’s race, altering the trajectory of the contest as the June 22 primary approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kit Dillon
title: Remember Picnics? Here Are Five Great Items to Make Yours Better.
description: Now that we’re starting to gather outdoors again, you can grill a better burger and keep the bugs at bay with these useful upgrades.
content: It can be hard to remember what it was like to freely socialize without anxiety, but with Covid-19 vaccines now available to all adults, our time of collective isolation appears to be waning. Even so, we’re still following distancing guidelines this spring, which means more small groups as we move our gatherings outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins and Nicole Hong
title: ‘Bro I Robbed Everyone’: 3 N.Y.P.D. Officers Charged in Bribe Scheme
description: The officers, one of them retired, funneled work to a tow truck company for kickbacks and sold car crash victims’ personal information, prosecutors say.
content: Two New York Police Department officers and a retired officer were charged Tuesday in federal court with running a yearslong bribery scheme that included kickbacks from a tow truck company and the selling of personal information of recent car crash victims to injury lawyers and physical therapists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Hindu Sect Is Accused of Using Forced Labor to Build N.J. Temple
description: Federal agents descended on the massive temple in Robbinsville, N.J., as a lawsuit charged that low-caste men had been lured from India to work for about $1 an hour.
content: Federal law enforcement agents descended on a massive temple in New Jersey on Tuesday after workers accused a prominent Hindu sect of luring them from India, confining them to the temple grounds and paying them the equivalent of about $1 an hour to perform grueling labor in near servitude.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘Dedicated’ Makes the Case for Choosing Something and Sticking With It
description: Pete Davis’s book grew out of a speech he gave to his Harvard Law School class about commitment, which has been viewed more than 30 million times online.
content: Before reading “Dedicated,” a new book by Pete Davis, I hadn’t realized that the acronym YOLO — you only live once — wasn’t always a celebration of doing something fleeting and reckless just for the thrill of it. One of its earliest public uses is attributable to the Grateful Dead drummer Mickey Hart; in the early 1990s, Hart poured his resources into a California property he called the YOLO Ranch, building a recording studio and creating a hub for the music community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Misleading C.D.C. Number
description: We have a special edition of the newsletter on a misleading C.D.C. statistic.
content: When the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released new guidelines last month for mask wearing, it announced that “less than 10 percent” of Covid-19 transmission was occurring outdoors. Media organizations repeated the statistic, and it quickly became a standard description of the frequency of outdoor transmission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Ethan Hauser
title: State and city universities in N.Y. will require vaccinations once the shots have full approval.
description: The sprawling SUNY system joins a growing list of academic institutions that plan to make a Covid-19 vaccination mandatory on their campuses.
content: The State University of New York and the City University of New York plan to require that all students attending in-person instruction in the fall be fully vaccinated against Covid-19, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Ai Fiori Expands With Its Sky Terrace
description: An airy restaurant in the Rockaway Hotel, a brick-and-mortar location for King David Tacos, and more restaurant news.
content: The Langham, a luxury hotel in Midtown Manhattan, is home to Ai Fiori, a serene Italian restaurant on its second floor. Now, an underused terrace on the 11th floor is being turned into an outdoor dining area, protected by red umbrellas, warmed with heaters and featuring a close-up view of the Empire State Building. It will serve cocktails and offer a dinner menu that’s an abridged version of the menu at Ai Fiori. The chef is Lauren DeSteno, the executive chef for Ai Fiori and a corporate executive chef for the Altamarea Group, where she oversees fine dining for restaurants including Ai Fiori and Marea. The chef Michael White, who was a founding partner of the restaurant group, is no longer involved with the company, according to Ahmass Fakahany, the founding partner who runs the company. Mr. White did not respond to inquiries from The Times. Now, Mr. Fakahany has been concentrating on promoting the women in his organization. “We have so much talent there,” he said. (In addition to Ms. DeSteno, Molly Nickerson has been the executive chef at Marea for the past two years, and Rachel Pancho is Ai Fiori’s pastry chef.) Osteria Morini and Nicoletta are the exceptions, in the hands of Bill Dorrler, also a corporate executive chef who oversees the many Morinis in the company’s portfolio. For the new terrace, Ms. DeSteno, 38, a Culinary Institute of America graduate who worked at Eleven Madison Park and has been with Altamarea for 12 years, has created a multilayered artichoke lasagna made with spinach pasta and a cloud of pecorino. She has not worked in Italy but has visited often. Her responsibilities with the company have also taken her to Dubai, the United Arab Emirates, and elsewhere in the Middle East. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: A key Senate panel deadlocked on Democrats’ election overhaul, signaling a murky path ahead.
description: The tie vote in the Rules Committee set up a showdown over the landmark voting rights expansion on the Senate floor in the months ahead. Republicans have vowed to stop it.
content: A key Senate committee deadlocked on Tuesday over Democrats’ sweeping proposed elections overhaul, setting the stage for a showdown on the Senate floor in the coming months that could determine the future of voting rights and campaign rules across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rula Salameh
title: What Life Is Like Right Now for Palestinians in East Jerusalem
description: The attempts by settlers to forcibly displace Palestinian families in the disputed city have galvanized broader opposition to the Israeli occupation.
content: JERUSALEM — I watched the wailing ambulances bring the injured, the medical staff carry them on stretchers and the nurses guide them into the emergency ward. I saw blood-soaked clothes and gauze-wrapped necks and faces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: New Drugs Could Help Treat Obesity. Could They End the Stigma, Too?
description: The hope is that new treatments will encourage people to think of obesity as a chronic disease, like high blood pressure or diabetes.
content: Obesity has stalked Marleen Greenleaf, 58, all of her life. Like most people with obesity, she tried diet after diet. But the weight always came back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Hispanic Democrats run ads targeting four House Republicans over their Jan. 6 votes.
description: The advertisements from the Congressional Hispanic Caucus focus on Republican members who represent heavily Latino districts and won close elections last year.
content: The political action committee of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus is releasing bilingual advertisements targeting four Republicans in Congress over their support for former President Donald J. Trump and their votes on Jan. 6 to challenge the 2020 presidential election results in Arizona and Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: C.D.C. Chief Defends Pandemic Guidance as Impatience Mounts
description: At a Senate hearing on the federal government’s pandemic response, Republicans criticized the government’s guidance for cruise ships, fishermen, summer camps and outdoor mask wearing.
content: WASHINGTON — The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Tuesday defended the agency against accusations that federal scientists were being too slow to update their pandemic-control guidance and overly conservative with their recommendations, especially on outdoor mask wearing.
source.name: The New York Times
